title: Terrified workers swap name tags to try stop stalking and sexual harassment
text:

Shop workers are swapping name tags to avoid the "gross" flirting of customers who have harassed and filmed them.

Women working in retail in Australia have spoken candidly about the treatment they receive while working on the shop floor.

Nyakim Nyuon has been employed in the fast food industry for three years.

The 21-year-old told the Sydney Morning Herald how she had been filmed without her consent by flirtatious customers.

Two of her co-workers swapped name tags after a visitor to the shop began stalking a colleague.

In the end she started wearing a tag with a fake name on it in the hope that the overreaching customer would be dettered.

(Image: Sydney Morning Herrald)

An anonymous respondent to the Australian Human Rights Commission survey on sexual harassment said: "Wearing a badge with our name on it makes customers and sexual predators feel comfortable enough to harass us under the guise of friendliness.

"It also allows them to think that because they know your name they are entitled to other personal information about you and to touch you.

"Wearing a name badge also makes it incredibly easy for those same predators to go home and look us up online and then harass us from the comfort of their homes.”

The research found that 39% of 3,413 retail, fast food and warehouse workers surveyed in Australia had experienced some kind of sexual harassment in the past five years.

Another woman spoke of a man slow moving closer to her as she worked in a restaurant.

“My harasser sits outside my work in the food court and watches me as I work," she said.

"If I notice him he averts his eyes but not for long. He also does his grocery shopping in my store and on the last occasion brought his wife with him.

"He has also started parking his vehicle closer to mine so I see it when I leave work.”

Selissa Damor became scared after she was contacted by a customer.

(Image: Getty Images)

"I've had customers message me outside of work on social media because they've seen my name tag," the 20-year-old told the SMH.

"I've had them try to call me and contact my family. They tried to message my younger brother who is still in school because I was ignoring their messages."

Kate Jenkins, sex discrimination commissioner, criticised the prevalence of sexual harassment in the workplace.

She said: 'Nobody should have to put up with this type of unacceptable behaviour at work. And yet we heard that harassment occurs in big and small business.

'That’s why it’s everyone’s business to eliminate sexual harassment."
description: The Australian Human Rights Commission looked at how prevalent sexual harassment directed at shop staff was
